abstracts.cdata!:
This program document proposes a
            single-tranche, stand-alone Development Policy Credit (DPC)
            for the Republic of Nicaragua. This DPC builds on the
            recently ended series of Poverty Reduction Support Credits
            (PRSCs). It is being proposed for strategic reasons to
            engage the authorities in a continuing policy dialogue and
            in the interests of maintaining a predictable periodicity in
            budget support disbursements, while the authorities prepare
            and consult their up-dated Poverty Reduction Strategy (PRS).
            As indicated in the last PRSP progress report, the
            authorities intend to strengthen the PRSP in response to
            what has been perceived as a very slow poverty reduction
            response to the strategy implemented so far. In particular,
            the authorities are seeking to deemphasize the privatization
            agenda, replace the previous 'cluster development
            strategies' with small and medium enterprise
            development models, and promote universal access to basic
            social services by lowering their costs. More generally, the
            revised strategy puts more emphasis than before on
            facilitating participation by small and medium producers in
            the growth process and on maximizing access to
            opportunities. The policy actions supported under the DPC
            focus mainly on public sector strengthening, with an
            emphasis on public sector management and transparency, and
            on strengthening the efficiency, monitoring and
            accountability of basic social services. These actions are
            drawn mainly from the first two of the four thematic areas
            covered by the common Performance Assessment Matrix (PAM)
            for joint financing arrangement, which are (i) macroeconomic
            stability and improvement of public sector and financial
            management; (ii) promotion of greater social and human
            capital development; (iii) inclusive economic development;
            and (iv) strengthen governance and accountability. These
            four thematic areas are broadly consistent with the focus of
            International Development Associations (IDA'S) current
            Country Partnership Strategy (FY08-FY12), whose lending
            program is anchored in a series of annual budgetary support operations.
